The Right Honourable Mzee Jomo Kenyatta

1st President of Kenya

Here's a time line of Mzee Jomo's life:

  • 1897 - Kenyatta was born in the village of Nginda
  • 1909 - Kenyatta left home and enrolled as a pupil at the Church of Scotland Mission (CSM) at Thogoto."
  • 1914 - Kenyatta moved to Thika, where he worked for an engineering firm run by Briton John Cook."
  • 1917 - Kenyatta moved to Narok, where he was involved in transporting livestock to Nairobi.
  • 1923 - Kenyatta had initially refused to cease drinking, but in July 1923 officially renounced alcohol and was allowed to return to Holy Communion.
  • 1924 - Kenyatta began working as a stores clerk and meter reader for Cook, who had been appointed water superintendent for Nairobi's municipal council.
  • 1929 - He travelled to London to lobby for Kikuyu land affairs.
  • 1930 - Jomo studied at Moscow's Communist University of the Toilers of the East, University College London, and the London School of Economics.
  • 1938 - He published an anthropological study of Kikuyu life before working as a farm labourer in Sussex during the Second World War.
  • 1946 - He returned to Kenya and became a school principal.
  • 1947 - He was elected President of the Kenya African Union
  • 1952 - He was among the Kapenguria Six arrested and charged with masterminding the anti-colonial Mau Mau Uprising.
  • 1961 - Kenyatta became President of KANU and led the party to victory in the 1963 general election.
  • 1964 - Kenyatta became its executive president, combining the roles of head of state and head of government.
  • 1966 - He amendment the constitution to give the president the ability to order the detention of individuals without trial if he thought the security of the state was threatened.
  • 1969 - Kenyatta's government resorted to un-democratic measures to restrict the opposition.
  • 1978 - He died of a heart attack in the State House, Mombasa.

"Fifty years ago, Kenya's founding father and first president Jomo Kenyatta made a promise to his new-born nation, there is much to celebrate, but Kenyans are also aware that this is not the country they might have expected as the British flag lowered over the capital half a century ago."

-- Aljazeera Africa Reporter Peter Greste

If you have time, you should read more about this incredible human being on his Wikipedia entry.
